That's where you actually have to prepare it yourself versus prepared food is up here. 01:01 That's like eating out restaurant demand delivery, et cetera. So I point out that Uber has already developed solutions for three of these categories of eating on-demand restaurant delivery, eating out and ordering pickup online at grocery delivery as well. 01:19 And I aim to kind of answer the question of whether or not Uber should build a solution for a fourth way of eating which is packaged meal delivery. 01:28 So this is like freshly where they send you a couple of meals that are frozen or refrigerated and you put them in the freezer and then when you're ready you heat it in two to three minutes. 01:40 So I really like to include a graphic here in this section to supplement the text just because it's a lot more visually interesting and helps people better understand like what are we actually focusing on. 01:54 Now the hypothesis I chose is that if UberEats offers packaged meal delivery, then they will increase retention amongst their user base. 02:03 Now the reason I chose this hypothesis was actually because the position that I was applying for was on the retention team itself. 02:12 So I knew that was something that they were looking for in this case study and it kind of intuitively make sense. 02:20 Packaged meals are typically ordered in bulk. title: Case Example: PayPal

Transcript: 0:00 In this lesson I'm going to go over the parts of a case study. Case study is one of the most important things for your product portfolio and I'm going to quickly give an overview of the different sections and then in later lessons I'll deep dive into each component of the case study. 0:17 So there are four main parts of the product development process and therefore the product case study. So this is what the double diamond product development process looks like. 0:29 There's kind of these two overarching parts of it. There's the problem over here and then there's the solution. So the idea is that you start with some type of challenge or insight and you diverge to really understand like what is actually happening here? 0:47 Like this is the time to look at competitors, look, listen to users and what they're saying and really just understand the problem and then you converge down and you really define what is the true core problem that our users are experiencing here, based on all the information we were able to gather 1:08 during this exploration phase. Then once you have a clear definition of the problem that you're trying to solve, then you diverge again and actually investigate different ways that you can develop solutions. 1:23 How can you solve this problem? What is the way that's going to be most effective? And then after testing it and learning more, you converge again and you end up with your final solution that is supposed to provide the most value for your users. 1:40 Now, within each of these sections, as you learn more, you kind of go in a loop. So, you might learn something that changes your idea of the problem and you might start to investigate other areas. 1:53 Similarly, for the solution area, you might start to test different prototypes or solutions and learn stuff about how users are interacting with it and go back to the drawing board and kind of iterate over and over. 2:08 So again, these four parts are what will actually be showing and working on in the case studies within your product portfolio. 2:18 So to give a little bit more detail here, the Discover F*** really involves researching the market, identifying problems in that market, and gathering information about the customers and their needs. 2:31 Next in Define, this is part two, in this stage the information you gathered in the Discover stage is actually used to further define the problem and state a clear goal for solving that problem. 2:45 And then in Develop, the third stage, the product is actually designed, developed and tested. It includes iterating on the product based on feedback from the user testing itself. 2:57 So this again is that loop of exploring solutions and actually trying to find the best one. And then deliver is the final stage where the final product is defined and prepared for launch. 3:10 There's really a focus on ensuring successful adoption of the feature with a go-to-market plan and identifying improvements based on user feedback. 3:20 So you want to make sure there are ways to measure success for your feature solution. So these are the four parts in future lessons I'm going to deep dive into each one of these to help you actually run a case study for yourself.
Short Description: Learn how to structure a product portfolio case study using the double diamond stages so you can document your process from problem discovery to launch-ready delivery.
title: Parts of a Case Study

title: Picking a Product / Problem

title: Sprint planning and review

She then worked closely with her team to prioritize the features and initiatives for the app. 1:00 So together, Sophia, the PM, the designer, and the engineers, they created an extensive product backlog detailing all the desired features and their relative importance. 1:12 So there were the p0, highest priority ones, tickets, there were p1s, p2s, p3s, p4s, etc. So Sophia now acting as the scrum master, she facilitated a sprint planning session where the team agreed on the goals for their first two week sprint. 1:28 They selected several high priority items from the product backlog and broke them down into smaller manageable tasks. So these are features that the team said, okay, to accomplish this feature, we want to make these five tasks that'll be available. 1:41 Build into that feature. Okay. The team committed to completing these tasks within the sprint timeframe. And they also conducted a sprint retro to discuss their successes, challenges, and opportunities for improvements in kind of more an internal setting. 2:30 Armed with this knowledge, the team adjusted their processes and set new goals for the next sprint. So over the next course of several months, the team continued to follow Agile process. 2:41 Over the course of iteratively delivering features and improvements every two weeks in these two-week sprints, they made data-driven decisions and continuously incorporated user feedback to ensure that the fitness tracking app met the needs of its target audience. 2:55 So through agile approach and close collaboration, the Innovate X team successfully launched this fitness tracking app, delivering a product that not only met but exceeded their users' expectations. 3:09 So hopefully this story showcased to you the power of agile methodologies in bringing a team together, enabling them to ship impactful features really quickly. 3:23 So, all in all, agile is a framework. Inclusive design is a broader concept that considers the diverse range of human abilities, preferences in situations when creating products or services. 0:46 So accessibility may be for someone who is deaf or blind, versus inclusive design may be for someone who can see, but can't see that well. 0:55 Or can hear, but can't hear that well. Or has processing issues, etc. So the goal is to create a product that can be used by as many people as possible without the need for adaptation or specialized design. 1:09 So the importance of accessibility and inclusive design. Um, by considering accessibility from the beginning, you can save time and resources compared to going back and retrofitting an existing product. 1:35 So if you're building a new product or you join a team where the product is already established, you'll still want to make sure that accessibility is front and center of the decision-making process. 1:49 Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, WCAG, I've heard this pronounced different ways, but this is a set of guidelines developed by the World Wide Web Consortium, W3C, to make web content more accessible to people with disabilities. 2:05 The guidelines are organized under four main principles, perceivable, operable, understandable, and robust. title: Accessibility and inclusive design principles

Short Description: Learn how to prepare for product management interviews by practicing key question types and researching the company so you can communicate confidently and leave a stronger impression.

Short Description: Learn how to apply proven PM interview tactics like showing passion, emphasizing impact, communicating clearly, and avoiding red flags so you can improve your chances of getting an offer.

Transcript: 0:01 Everyone in this lesson 6.5 I'm gonna go over tech debt and it's impact on overall product development So a quick intro here ultimately strike a balance between, you want to deliver features quickly, but you also want to ensure long-term maintainability and scalability. 0:39 So in this lesson, we're going to go into these topics and how basically it impacts the ultimate product development process. 0:48 Okay, so understanding TechDead. The definition here is, TechDead is really the result of trade-offs made during the software development process. 0:58 Teams typically will prioritize speed over quality or using outdated technologies to save time and resources. An example, a quick example here, is that a team they choose to implement a feature quickly using a less optimal solution, knowing that in the future they're going to need to revisit that and 1:16 refactor it. But they did that so that they could get it more quickly out to users. And this is a typical concept that you'll see. 1:24 Companies want to move fast. They want to be able to compete. And so they're willing to make these trade-offs and write code that is not really optimal and we'll have to be changed in the future. 1:37 Some causes here. So what actually goes into creating technical debt? It can arise from a variety of different factors. One I mentioned is type deadlines. 1:47 Another is inadequate resources. So if the team was bigger or we just kind of had more time, we'd be able to invest in a better solution. 1:56 Another is around lack of documentation or changes in the requirement. So an example here is that a development team may be pressed for time because we have to reach a specific deadline. 2:07 And so they will decide to skip writing all tests for the new feature. And this means that later on the feature may start breaking. 2:15 And so tech debt is basically what we've now created by our decision to move fast and skip writing these tests, and later on, we're going to have to go back and address that at some point. 2:29 So what is the impact on TechDead? The first one is around increased maintenance costs. So as TechDead really builds up and accumulates, the cost of actually maintaining the software goes up and up, and ultimately it causes you to consume more resources and time. 2:47 An example here is that a product could be built using outdated framework, and that That doesn't require a more effort to update and maintain over the long term, and the time it takes to actually make those updates takes away from new feature development. 3:02 And so TechDead is one of those things where it, you know, creating it to move fast in the first place may be necessary, but then it always kind of comes around and, you know, hurts you in the end. 3:15 The second one here is reduced development velocity. So, if you have a lot of tech debt that builds up over time, it's in a slow down the development process. 3:25 And this means that every time you add tech debt, later on when you want to add a new feature, it's going to be even longer and more complicated to do so because the code base is riddled with all this tech debt. 3:37 So this example of how this could impact your team is that you come up with this new feature and hypothetically, it should take just two weeks, but once the engineers actually get into the code and start making changes, they see that there's a ton of tech debt that is slowing them down and causing them 3:56 to have to refactor things, and this turns a two week project into a four week project. Now, combine that and compound that over multiple different features, and you're now doubling the amount of time it's taken to update your product. 4:10 And this is what happens when companies, you know, year after year as it builds and they grow the product more and more tech debt is created. 4:19 And that's why the bigger the company, kind of the slower they can go because there's so much code, there's so much complexity as opposed to a newer team where the code is all fresh and new and they're able to move really fast. 4:33 The third impact here is generally lower code quality. So as you build up tech debt over time, it can result in the code being less quality, which means it's more difficult to maintain, more difficult for someone who is coming into that file to understand what's going on and be able to build and expand 4:53 off of it. An example here is that a complex, poorly documented code base is harder for new team members to understand and contribute to, leading to slower progress and potential errors. 5:05 So these are all the different things. Basically all this goes into the fact that it's gonna take more time to release new functionality, the more tech debt that you have. 5:18 Okay, so how do you actually manage tech debt? So the first is you wanna regularly assess it and track it. 5:25 So if you decide to skip over something out of speed, speed, you want to just immediately create a ticket in your project management tool to address that at a later stage. 5:39 You could also use tools like SonarCube or other code analysis tools that help you and help the engineers identify areas of the code base that may require refactoring or improvements in the future. 5:52 Now, the second is that you actually want to prioritize addressing tech debt. You want to allocate time and resources to address tech debt in the development schedule to minimize its long-term effects. 6:04 So what I typically see is that teams may do like an 80-20 split where 80% of the time in every two weeks is spent working on new features, new functionality, whereas 20% is addressing kind of these longer-standing tech debt items. 6:21 Now, if your team has a lot of tech debt, they may decide, you know what, for the next two weeks, we are just going to tackle tech debt. 6:29 We need to address this. But the more standard approach, more popular approach is to do kind of this split framework where 80 to 90 percent of these two weeks sprints are dedicated to new features and updating functionality, fixing bugs, and the other 10 to 20 percent are addressing tech debt. 6:48 But the third here is balancing short-term and long-term needs. So you want to make informed decisions when faced with trade-offs between what is considered a quick fix and long-term maintainability. 7:01 And an example here is that you may wait the benefits of implementing a feature quickly against the potential long-term costs of addressing the resulting tech debt. 7:11 So you may say that, okay, we could get this feature out one week faster. But if we do that, we're going to add three weeks in the future to address the tech debt that we're creating. 7:24 Or we can just spend the time now, it'll push back our release date by, you know, half a week or a full week, and we won't have created that tech debt. 7:34 So there's always these kind of trade-offs that you're needing to make and you're going to collaborate and really partner with your engineering team to make these trade-offs and decisions in an educated way. 7:45 Okay, so that was the lesson on tech debt. It's really a critical factor for PMs to at least consider in the development process. 7:54 By understanding what causes it in the first place, how it impacts the teams, and a couple of different ways to manage it, PMs can make more informed decisions that balance short-term needs, the need to get something out really fast versus long-term needs, which means maintaining the product over time 8:11 , scaling the product over time, and ultimately being super-success So that's tech debt. Short Description: Learn how to identify technical debt causes, impacts, and management strategies so you can balance fast feature delivery with long-term maintainability and development speed.
title: Tech debt and impact on product development
